values:
I think I like Layering ideas.  I think the best ideas are always layered.  I think the best writing is layered with multiple skins of comprehensible meanings.  Fine Artists are always speaking about "The Audience's Interpretation" rather than the artist's intent.  'Course I think most people in general would look at an abstract expressionist painting and bring nothing to it, because it doesn't bring anything to them.  It might provoke the statement such as "I like that color." LAME. But rather than "the Audience's Interpretation" I prefer to think that a piece of artifice can have multiple layers, not so ambiguous thus resulting in the audience leaving with a feeling of an intimate connection with the thing, but in order for the audience to get engaged they need to have a stronger reaction than "Gee, I like the color purple" .  Sometimes people mistake ambiguity for artistic meaning. (You'll see that all too often in a lot of "postmodern" independent flims.  In addition to a severe deficit for plot structure/any ending at all.  Broken Flowers was mostly just pointlessly extended shots of Bill Murray sitting in a room somewhere staring off into space with a vacant expression.) When it really is just ambiguity sometime for the sake of itself, but hopefully for the sake of some concept that is comprehensible or interesting in some way.  I'm talking about any type of artifice here: drawing, painting, writing, frozen pee carvings, what have you. (If you have frozen pee carvings you might be onto something.)

END.

Reality is a wretched thing.  Everything I've ever done creatively feels like only a bookmark for some grandiose idea that I began with.  In fact, I can't help feel that anyone who destroys their lives by producing whatever type of artifice it is they produce must inherently possess some type of disconnect with reality, or at least a large bit of naivety.  
With the exception of writers.  To me, it seems that if I come up with a piece of writing it somehow always represents the "thing" I'm trying to get at, even in rough.  Perhaps its the process of simplification through these symbols somehow imbues them with the meaning of the writer, especially because a symbol can mean whatever you want it to, however if you're trying to draw a damn spaceship, everyone can tell when you effed it the hell up.  Why is that?  It's like drawing is a window into the mind's eye and they know when you're lying to yourself,  at least in terms of representational work.  I suppose that's why so many artists have "ascended" into abstraction.  Its a lot harder to tell an abstract expressionist when he or she's screwed up, (unless you believe that the act itself is screwy, hah) 

Its not fair, I say!

I think I'm about three hours away from calling myself a "spanner."
***
BRIAN LAMB RAWKS!!!

I just spent the last two days making drawing and painting with very few actual breaks, some for sleep and some for food.  As exhausted as I am I can only think about the next thing I'm going to make.  Is this endless?
I'm sorry I didn't save you Kanjers. I'm sorry I didn't do the right thing before it was too late.

52 fluid ounces of pop and 1 iced starbucks coffee later that morning.  My one statement of the early morn is: I would rather shoot myself in my own knee caps and eat my own eyeballs before I will "EVER" take on any design job in my life. 

Page Layout Designers must be the accountants of the art world. 

They do the shit that agonizes everyone else in the art world and get paid hansomely for it. Lack of creativety has rendered them partially souless, making it impossible for them to be bored. How can one be bored if one has no desire to do anything in the first place?

My design teacher, Chadwick would of course urges the painfully hackneyed pooper: "think outside of the box kiddoes"  Unfortunately, it seems that any desire to be experimental has been crushed by fear or doubt.  True, my motivation has dwindled so, that until now I was convinced I was in a serious crea-juice slump. 

I just spent the last two full nights working on this last design. 
Lovely: roughly one week to throw together a beast of a pamphlet that contains a veritable ass of copy text. which sucks.
Chad's painful acceptance of his inability to draw has given him a warped typi-hype trips and use that sexy san-serif on that coy L for some serious anal prostate nasturbations. 
 
Leave me out of it.

A recent random encounter with a Gregory Schauble outside the walls of Rutledge led to a discussion about graduation or better known as "How I Learned to Start Worrying and Hate the Real World." Greg's a photo teacher at Winthrop and has a few sons, his older two were illustration/multimedia majors and went on to complete grad school. One went to American University in DC but I did some research and the only vaguely related graduate studies program was "Communications" Blah. But Dave opened my eyes to SVA in New York a while ago with a particular focus on "Illustration as a Visual Essay" An interesting facet of the program incorporates creative writing, so its right up my ally. We'll see what happens.

I pulled out the ol' acrylic paints for a bit of random play.  When I do this its usually because I'm bored and don't want to think about anything very seriously, but I came to a strange realization.  As I was painting the situation of a couple of kids being boisterous around their sleeping father plopped into my head without any logical thought that would precede this one.  As we know, nothing is truly random and I realized that the reason that situation had surfaced was because I was simulateously painting a excited light greenish yellow glaze over a muted patch of paint that was already dried.  When paint is dried and can be painted over again without disturbing the surface you call it "isolated." Strangely I believe that the act of this situation in throwing paint down had somehow inspired an inadvertant analogic situation (the kids and the sleeping dad)  

How is this possible?  

The isolated muted color is to the loud bright nonisolated colors
as the dormant father is to the boisterous childens

I don't really see why it manifested itself that way. Regardless, it's fun to see how analogies are innately part of the psychological process. 
Maybe in some stretch of the imagination those american expressionists that I have such great difficulty understanding are actually writing narrative.  No.. probably not.
Yeah... The new Decemberists Album: The Crane Wife... Not impressed. Actually, I'm severely disappointed.  What the hell.
I've decided to take on Han Solo is my personal role model when it concerns romantic situations.

Rachel took me to the wrap party for the film "Patriotville."   I met a bunch of people and maybe two of them I actually thought as quality human beings, but the majority of them didn't strike me as particularly motivated or interesting people.  A great deal of the crew members probably didn't even have a college degree.  They were really the blue-collar end of the industry.  I didn't mind being there really but it was probably because I had one too many beers.  A couple faces like Ernesto the venezuelian set designer kept me there and it was funny to see all the diverse types working on the film.  It also makes me quirk a brow at how six unpaid interns all happened to be decently attractive female youths.  So yeah.  There was that.  I got to talk with Erin for a while and that was good.  At some point I danced on the same dance-floor as Jason Long.. OMFG!!... no not really *thumbs down* he sucks bad, and I don't mean his dancing,  I mean his overall personality is very crappy.. very.  In that whole "Short Smarmy Macperior Goobish " category.  Though I don't think he uses macs.  He just promotes them while standing bow-legged in comfortable looking airwalks.  It tickles me pink to think that Apple is actually trying to approach marketing computers from that whole highschoolian peer pressure angle. It won't be too long before other practical office supplies like staplers and 3 hole punches will be sold using the same technique.  
Another detail from the evening at the bar was this rather large sign made up of a series of flourescent neon tubing that read,

"If you don't like country music, you can kiss our ass"

And ass was written in a different flourescent color... red I think. Not very clever.  Long Branch you suck too.  So Winthrop is kinding of taking it up the butt from the whole "Asylum" movie that's being shot on campus.  They closed off half of Oakland (the road that divides Winthrop into two pieces.  And I no longer go to Winthrop,  I go to Richard-Miller Univ.  I also found out its being directed by a stunt man.  Figures... anyone can get into this business.  No wonder there are so many shitty movies out there.  Everyone's got a script and a lot of them for the worse, become films.

I just finished heaving many pounds of art supplies, studio furnitures, And old Sketch Books filled with embarassingly poorly drawn cat-people into my new studio at the lodge.  That shit is my bane, and I cannot help, for whatever reason, blaming it, or at least realizing the correlation to my accumulation of said shit and it's displacement of excellent friendships.  I regret my defunct social skills which have been replaced by a few year's experience with a dull blade and an inky brush, and I am sorry for it.  
Before this I loved my friends and the people I was around, and while I still care for my old best friends, though we have grown far apart, I still love them, or at least the impression of what it was we all had. I cannot stand this estrangement I feel when I do see them and how time apart has fermented into a poison against our kinship.  I am glad that many of them are able, now, to reconvene and surround themselves with each other again, but I admit that this also amplifies my envy.
I do not understand why it is, that to follow our dreams, or to go down the path we want, why we must sever our roots, or maybe sever isn't the right word, perhaps roots just wither, but for whatever reason, whether it is due to physical distance, or my ridiculously bad social skills, I am sorry about it and I hope that there is some time in the future that will compensate for my absence.  I'm sorry I haven't been there.

Hurray, my first published design/illustration work on a major university website: Dacus Library Virtual Tour!! *Oh and Congratulations to Erin for getting a paid graphic design position with the film "Patriotsville" *And also Congrats to Lucy for getting a childrens' book published!

With progress on my senior thesis project Little Boy Blue I progressively find how much more and more I appreciate film and want to take part in it for a career. I've been saturating my mind with "the making of ..." docs, mainly the Lord of the Rings ones, which there are collectively 15 hours or more of. I remember spending most of my childhood building things and imagining things. I remember laying out this velvety green mat onto the carpet of what was known in my house as "the play room." I would pile this mat high with articulate lego works of architecture, but I enjoyed more moving the little people around with the other toys: Micromachines, Megaforce, tiny collectable robots called "Z-Bots!", tiny collectible aeroplanes. I always made up scenarios in my head and imagined the pov from within my little sets, which is exactly what they were, sets. And I pair this memory now with the recent images of Peter Jackson scrutinizing the placement of tiny little green army men, of which there were thousands, all signifying orcs. One of my fondest memories of my childhood was collaborating with my brothers on this game we were "making" called PowerKid! or PK for short, of course. We were inspired by the original computer games we played... The original 2d Duke Nukems and especially Commander Keen the foe of evil vortican aliens and unbeknownst to the world a child genius. I was able to coerce my brothers into this prepubescent pipe-dream by sheer force of personality and charisma and though their involvement in my project was fleeting, I still pride myself on being able to hold their interest and inspire them even if it were only for a couple weeks of a dull summer. I get so great of pleasure out of remembering these things and thinking of applying them and actively applying them within my own project. I recently completed a small project for Dacus Library where I worked full-time this summer. They wanted me to put together a collection of fourteen individual drawings of two different characters that would act as playful tour guides on the Winthrop Dacus Website for the "Virtual Tour." A series of webpages designed introduce Freshman to The library's facilities. I was showered with compliments but it wasn't exactly my best work. Still though, it got the stuffy Dean's attention and he apparently brought up my name and his pride in the project during some staff meeting. I'm not sure about the details. I wasn't there. But being the art department for Dacus was interesting. There is a keen mysticism to various arts and crafts, and people who are able to be involved in such types of projects get blessed with attention for it. Still, I see a distinction with those brave piligrms of such crafts to be ambitious rather than talented, but I suppose by definition they are the same thing. Perhaps I will be able to be part of a really amazing project one day. I have a strange addiction to challenges and extended hours of work, that is of course if there is clear dedication of myself and those working by my side.

Stop-mo film proj blog now located at:

http://littleboybluefilm.blogspot.com

This one is better, with more graphics, more pictures, and more sketches. If you care about my life at all then take a look.

For those of you whos' eyes have grazed these pages before may you very well may remember my past experiences with awkward gay men, either older or of... a compromised appearance in unexpected places of business, I am refering specifically to the the Afro-American Prince of Jack-In-The-Box. Those of you know me also know of the chemical-ridden tears I've shed for non-caloric fizzy pop.(of which there has been rivers of to speak of, yes... no.) These cravings drive me to visit the local covenient store on a regular basis, perhaps once or a twice a day. Let me introduce you to the ostensibly innocent quick-e-mart employee who I will refer to as "Chyuck." Chuck is a middle-aged walking ogre with a light reddish blonde hair, with thick sweaty sausages for fingers, and complete with a-cup breasts and a gut. He wears a playful bright-eyed expression which says, "My life is a waste but I'm still here for the peanuts!" Chuck is not chuck's real name. But I doubt his name is Daniel, nor ... perhaps Maximilian nor Hieronymus. Chuck likes to tell people when he checks them out, to say that instead of oweing per se $1.25 that they owe: "hunderd an' twenny-faiv dallors" He does this habitually and obviously after the one-hundred and twenty-fifth time its strangle worthy. I suppose he could be a Gary, But that's probably because it has a aural likeness to the word "Gay." Yes this entry is about gay and it is about very gay, awkwardly gay, and please-sir-if-you-don't-mind-I-would-prefer-if-you-refrained-from-penetrating-my-person-with-the-tip-of-your-thumb-gay, which of course never happened but let me tell you... I have in fact endured occasional invasions of the body, in that I mean while filling up the 44 oz. styrofoam buckets with diet colas, This man has: 1.)poked the sides of my reserved for girlfriend only, lovehandles simultaneously on both sides in a hastey flourish. 2.)Tugged on the back of my hankerchief which hangs from my back left pocket, dangerously close to my buttocks while executing a rather disruptive "Krek!" by forcing the air in his mouth out from between the back of his tongue and back molars... The Kicker: These invasions, while awkward and annoying are tolerable and as stated before, are not extreme, the kicker is far more... hilarious. Enter Joey into the nearby BP quick-mart confronted by Chuck in his normal attire, "Weeeell hellu thur" he says to me leaning casually over the fountain machine (mildly midwestern/Watered-down irish decent accent with a little bit of southern drawl just for effect), I approach the fountain machine cautiously Chuck offers the 44 oz. Bucket, I retrieve and fill. Here is when I make the mistake, when I get to the counter, I jokingly say "Oh, and yes this is a refill." cue the ever-so rich in homo-erotic metaphoric overtones in all their sticky splendor: "Re fill.. reeefill my buutt, I'll refill you, I'll refill you to the brim-with-a-rim... An awkward, shocked glare "Aint that right." silence and dot-dot-dot Ahem. Places exact cash and change on table... look away. "Aint it?" What... Bye. You may all come to your various conclusions about the interpretation of what "Brim with a Rim" actually means.

In an effort to find effective ball/socket parts for my stopmotion project puppets, Rachel suggested that I look into legos bionicles or k'nex. It seems that Bionicles is an branch of legos that has, indeed, developed a new set of ball/socket parts that work rather effectively. So I went out and bought the 4 dollar "Matoran Garan." Immediately upon opening the box and pulling in a mouthful of fresh ABS Plastic Fumes that the blocks are made out of, my childhood memories broke the dam of my adulthood and came rushing in. Rachel bought me this motha'fucka for our six monther: Pretty GD amazing huh? He's the Stealth Hunter. Its the new "Exo-Force" Line of Lego toys. They're basically Denmark's Answer to Gundams, Xenogears, Exosuits, or any other "man-meets-gigantic-kick-ace-robot" phenomenon. My confession is that I must have all these toys and that I'm delcaring retirement from my dark ages of legos and begging these stupid pieces of delicious plastic for forgiveness upon realizing how life has been a complete waste of time without them. In addition to returning to my original career plan of moving to Denmark and working for Legoland in any corner they'll have me. Here are some other Exoforce pitchas: And lets not forget, Legos are now doing DINOSAURS okay that's enough. *sigh.*

Blah blah blah yes the summer is here.

Anyways I was digging through You-Tube for Winthrop Videos and found this:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vA-iFDU0doA&search=winthrop

"Your Savior."

This is an entry from my senior project lj: lilboybluefilm I figured it was about time to start uploading some of my sketches of the concept art for "Little Boy Blue." Below is a visual example of my thinking process of developing the robotic version of the main character, the boy, who I've described before as being a severely autistic young boy who imagines a world of automation for himself to thrive in: and If you like what you see, don't forget to friend me: lilboybluefilm
And tomorrow's Jewelry and Metals Critique will mark the end of my junior year classes.
Hey friends. If you're curious about my senior year project then check out this log: Little Boy Blue It's a stop-motion animated short flim. I've got about a year minus 2 weeks.

I don't know how it happened, but the retards that came to "fix" the disgusting sewage leak in the backyard literally left not only the door from our house to the basement wideopen, but they also left the basement door to the outside WIDE open.  So this means for the duration of the night the cats had complete and easy access to the outside. 

Why must I live in a world with retards?

Everytime I step foot into the Rock Hill walmart I lose a substantial amount of respect for the human race.  It would not be problem if they were only severely hideous, but their blatant unkemptness and general aura of stench, in addition to the way said appearance has rendered them mind-boggling abominations of the third deadly sin, has convinced me that if this whole illustration thing doesn't work out than I shall reign righteousness upon the people by removing all and any male reproductive organs of the south carolinian populas by measuring the degree of their southern dialect.  

It wouldn't be that bad.

I would just stop shopping at walmart to preserve what humanity I have left in me, but as you can see, they've been sent to my frontdoor masked with a silly vapid gaze and a few random metal tools with which to hammer on things.  Is it really that hard to believe that we came from ape-like species?  Sometimes I think we evolved from Roaches.

In light of the fact that I'm "holy-shit wtf am I going to do" behind this semester I have decided to purchase a bottle of alcohol, and a bottle of caffeine. (no not a bottle of pills, are you insane?) and I'm going to go into my studio and work for no less than 7 hours tonight on my current projects. 
 
Caffeine + Alcohol + Audiobook

I don't plan on getting drunk. Just a bit beyond tipsy. It's been a while.  Besides, its strictly for the sake of the greater good!

No more paralysis! 
No more perfectionism!
No more ... yeah!!!

*shakes fist in the air angrily*

I've been thinking a lot about my family lately. I have a considerably amount of guilt having to do with this subject.  I was probably, by far, the most vindictive child in my family and probably the craftiest at hurting people's feelings.  This of course is one of the great black stains in my personality which I am somewhat ashamed of depending on my mood, and if you know me, I am terribly moody.  Specifically my oldest brother and one of my little sisters received the brunt of this vindiction and I really feel terrible about it.  I used to make fun of petty things, yes, but I used to say them because I know they were insecure about those things.  Its funny, my brother's worst comeback (they never instigated), was "B-Boy."  Which within the context of our family (Both my brother's were unfaltering straight A students) was a considerably strong insult I suppose.  It was the best he could do and it wasn't very mean because I did indeed pride myself on being less obsessed with grades than them.  My insults always felt more cruel and I was "always" the instigator.  Almost always. So to either of those syblings reading this I apologize to you from the bottom of my heart.

On an almost completely unrelated point which I wrote more for myself than anyone else:
I wish I could draw on the fly a lot better.  I wish I could draw directly from my unconscious more.  Mainly illustrate from my unconscious.  To me it seems like there are two different ways to create something if you polarized them

Structured/Cerebral Developmental 

And

Organic/Intuitive Experimental

In the former of the two the artist would plan out the composition and all the elements in it.  Know the exact purpose for each element and how it functioned in the piece.  The artist would also make lots of sketches: line art sketches, tonal, sketches; color studies, and quite possibly gestural sketches.  Finally the artist would take that information, which they either developed or referenced from and would translate it to the final piece verbatim.  Sounds kind of stiffling huh?  Because Illustration tends to be more concrete and precise about its function,  I feel that it might lean to this side.  Also, a pity. 

In the latter of the two the artist would not plan out compositions.  The artist might practice in the sketch book gestural sketches, but the process would be more of an exercise or warm up but rather than be used line by line in the final piece.  The artist might do color studies but this too would be an exercise.  Quite possibly the artist could even start on the final piece without any practice for that piece.  Furthermore the artist might start the piece out in abstract forms based on very unconscious decisions.  At some point in the piece the artist would decide to begin interpretting some of those abstract forms into concrete shapes or objectification.  

In conclusion I would like to say that a great deal of my work paralyzes me in ways that I sometimes can't understand.  I have never really tried the latter effectively for an actual illustration project but I certainly am going to give it a shot.  Pieces could direct themselves where they go without me stiffling them.  I don't know.  I have to get comfortable with the fact that I'm generally always confused about artist approach.

Write.. write,  draw, paint, panic, pant, society of illustrators - heartbeat?, paint, breathe, drink, paint.  Write short stories, House, Broken Car, Lease leaving lease.... New house, old house? Breathe, Money, broke.  Pasteurized American Cheese, Decaf tea, living room of guitars. Cannon-ball sized litter clumps. Not so delicious.  

Silence.

Between being in Illustration classes where "the big message" is number one priority and my creative writing classes where precision and directed thought rule the quality of the craft, I've been getting pretty damn exhausted.  

Once I remember one of my friends trying to explain to me that you can judge the overall quality of art or writing by how well the artist or writer fulfilled the goal of what they intended; that somehow art was completely about "intention" - oh, the undeniable power of that word.  Eh... I guess?  That guy didn't know what he was talking about.
Recently I was reading up on some H.G. Wells' philosophy on writing fiction.  The source which I encountered claimed that H.G. Wells' had established two schools of thought when it came to producing a story:
"Undirected Thought" 
and 
"Directed Thought"
(cue thunderous roar)
The writer went on to explain that Wells thought of undirected thought as sloppy yet imaginative, stimulating but hardly precise. He perceived directed thought as a superior philosophy on writing because it is simplified and cuts away unncessary fat tissue from the meat of the issue, the muscle. Of course I love cheeseburgers and pastries so I can't really agree completely with this philosophy.

The writer proposed a good argument against this "clean" writing.  He basically argued that if you use all creative resources to make only a singulary point then you are obliterating the true potential for the unexplained human phenomenon which is to dream. Dreams don't have overall purposes.  Sometimes they might feel as though they do but a great deal of the time pieces of information, vivid imagry, emotions are all ambiguous symbols which rely on abstract concepts that don't have to have a sacred "point." He also compared dreams to history.  History doesn't have an overall point in mind, nor a writer, unless you believe in god, in which case god's logic would be to oblong or obscure to understand in a rational sense anyways.  

How refreshing.

I don't know why I am awake.  I've been awake since 5am I think.  Can't sleep.  Been thinking alot about creative identity? (I guess you'd call it that.)  Who are you... a writer, a musician, an artist, a sculptor, poet, packaging scientist?  Is it important that people think of you as a "--er, -ian, -ist?"  In the studio I make many things: paintings, drawings, sculptures, short stories, and songs even.  I can see myself doing various projects of any and all of these areas.  I guess its never really about the media to me, that is not to say that I don't like the process, rather I feel that the creative process is basically the same for any of these areas:  

you get inspired, 
you get a desire to express something, 
you explore the craft, 

and

you produce the thing. 

I suppose I've just been feeling rather overwhelmed lately.  You see, I could see myself being any and all of those professions.  It just so happens that illustration is the name of my study on paper. The greatest fear of all is becoming a jack of all trades but master of none.  That is, if you consider trades as forms of manipulating media rather than an all inclusive way of realizing an idea in any form. blah blah blah.

I guess this is why I value refinement in taste in myself and others.  There's so many things I want to do, I  feel that it is of grave importance that I know exactly what I like and exactly what I do not like.  I must piss off an awful lot of people because I'm sure I come off as fervently opposed to many things which I have absolutely no interest in.  The trick, I think, is to keep from ignoring it all the while.  Tunnel vision is a dangerous route.  Large Semi's and the like. That's what Back to the Future taught me anyways.  That and that hoverboards would be an excellent mode of transportation if it were ever feasible...
I passed specialization review for illustration.  I will be moving onto the next set of classes in spring.

Taking one day at a time is a philosophy that isn't appreciated well enough.

On that note, I have a story.
I felt the usual dull thirst for aspartame and other delicious carcinogenic chemicals and decided it was time to replenish my supply of diet pop.  On hearing a request for food by Rachel I figured it best that we sought these things at the nearest open grocery store which is the 24hrs Harry's Peeter located some miles from the house. Paul also had a hankering for waffles (specifically of the non-blueberry persuasion, as he refused mine)
and so he decided to join us on our expedition.
We are discussing various things and as Rachel is driving up india hook road we look over to two cars down in front of us and we see, yes, a stray car aimlessly coasting down the wrong side of the road.  Well this wasn't very good at all.. And this was mainly because other cars were coming down that side of the road in the opposite direction as the aimless meanderer, if I may use that as a noun.  We had spotted a cop with his lights off before watching this person do this and so we wonder where the cop was at this moment.  Not surprising.  The other cars kind of edged their way "slowly" around the car and kept doing so until the meanderer realized where he was.  
He then swurved into the left turn lane and paul says "he must think we're on a two lane highway.. hahaha" and then Rachel says "I really don't want to watch someone die tonight" and I agreed. All the while I was suspecting what type of drugs this poor bastard was on.  It could have been alcohol, or even acid, but I came to the conclusion that it was Crystal Meth.. Mainly because this is Rock Hill and Meth is Rock Hill's fuel.  Rock Hill.  or Rock Crystal Meth. or Meth Hill. OR Hill o' Crystal Meth Beans on lightly toasted, buttered bread.  CAN YOU hear the Snap, crackle, pop? 
We cautiously trailed behind the crazy meth meanderer and watched him stop at a green light, almost careen into a median, and almost swurve into another car in another lane.  
Paul got his waffles, I got my fix, and Rachel got nothing.

But I am sure of one thing.
It was definitely Meth.

There doesn't seem to be a reason to update other than the fact that I haven't since my birthday.

Seeing everyone was enjoyable, regardless of how different I think we all are.  I am thankful for my family.  Even if my use of language, or experiences with a few mild substances alienates me somewhat from the rest of em'.  I think my brothers understand the most.  

I recorded about 80 minutes of my family talking in the car on the way to my grandmother and grandfather's home. It is mainly my oldest brother andy, who's an entymologist, disgussing his research project which involves the study of honey-bee traits and their corresponding strings of genetic material.  He doesn't like genetics but he doesn't mind it so much. Its 80 minutes long and will soon be in mp3 form.

My grandparents live in brevard.  It is a very pleasant city nestled in a valley of the old appalachian mountains, about 30 miles southwest of Asheville.  They live in a smaller division of Brevard called Pisgah Forest, one of the most beautiful places in the southeast. I would not mind living there.  As I've probably explained before, my grandparents (on my father's side of the family) is the only place which I've been able to watch age as I aged.  They never moved.  We always moved, and so this mountaineer instinct is in my blood.

Of the five children in my family I think I come off as the most cynical, next to my oldest brother Andy, who is also cynical, but I also come off as the most deviant as well, or at least have the curse of feeling the most deviant in the family. (common middle child syndrome) A mentality which seems to become more prevalent with the increase of the quantity of siblings in a family.  
I also enjoy shocking my family members the most, mainly to get a reaction.  In the past I think I was annoying, but now its more entertaining I hope.  I was at the mall with Mark and my two sisters and there is a loud baby crying and I say over to kim,

"Hey how about I punch that baby really hard in the face and then look to the mother and say "Get it?!" and then start laughing?"  

Then of course she'd give me that "oh my gosh" expression: 1 part amusement, 4 part surprise, and 1 part disgust.  Either way it makes for an excellent after-dinner dessert.

This comment then translated into a new term "baby-punching." As if it were some kind of new form of recreation, which could be used casually in and out of normal conversation. 


At my grandparents house we opened gifts and I tolerated conversation with my aunt and her third husband. I like my aunt an' all but they're both very normal and boring. 

My grandfather drove me from brevard to rock hill which is about a 3 hour trip.  
We talked about Women and Golf. 

Merry christmas.

Ah, it has been a while indeed. 

So now a recollection of my birthday. It was a small collection of my favorite people, minus a few due to distance and/or more important obligations. The day began early for me, around 11am. (heh heh) As usual on fridays, because the lack of classes, I go immediately to the studio to get some work done on various projects which I am trying to juggle all at a time, while simultaneously saturating my brain with the Making of the Lord of the Rings Film knowledge.  (Yes, the emac in the studio has a dvd reader)  

At approximately 7:00pm I return to my studio from talking with Jill in rutledge about how uncertain the futures of art majors are and I am greeted by Matthew Sutherland and Christopher Vinson who are waiting by the door.  Vinny explains how they are both abducting me to take me to dinner, I accept and then Paul joins the party.  He is armed with a birthday present.  It is the full storyboards and some of Dave Mckean's artwork from Mirrormask. (see previous entry for more information on this film) Its a wonderful present.  

We go to Chinese Delicacy and partake of dinner.  Matt buys a bottle of sake.  It was very tasty and a very good appetizer for my meal. After flirting with the vietnamese waitress and paying the bill, we head back to Jessica Bitner's Residence for conversation.  We spend mosto f the time in her room watching old saturday morning television show openings.  It was a nostalgic experience.  How appropriate for my 22nd birthday, yes? We were joined by Rachel and Garrett for a bit at the time as well as Thomas who was there for a spell. 

the night concluded with myself being here working on more artwork.  

It was a lovely birthday.  I enjoyed how intimate it was, and the day really kind on encapsulates the mood of the semester for me:

30% Social happenings
65% School
5%  Sleep and Food.
Mirror Mask - the answer is definite yes. This is "the" best film I've seen this year or two. Paul is such a great matchmaker.
Damn you first succulent step: inspiration, you deceitful dream, you.
I had a dream I masturbated a small tortoise.

I've come to a realization about my biggest problem right now concerning my the things I create.

I don't make enough of it, Yet my sketch book is filled with tons upon tons of ideas.  I spend so much time conceptualizing and dreaming about projects that its hard for me to sit down with something and just attack it with media.  this is partially due to how the illustration class is set up this semester, but its mostly my own problem of over-conceptualization. The same goes for material I've written on guitar.   I have many songs, melodies and even some lyrics, but I have difficulty finishing any of my songs unless there's some reason to. 

The truth is I've become far too indulgent with my dreams.  But now its time to start making myself make things intuitively, without restraint.
THE ANTS ARE INVADING! GOD HELP US.

Let me first add: hell yeah.

Paul and I drove for about 2 hours and 42 minutes to get to Asheville. We arrived about 2 hours before the show started: enough time to walk the streets.  The usual musicians with their own burned cd's laying next to them in stacks,  A woman painted silver standing at a town corner.  A strange drum beat ensemble in the center of the city; Paul bought some watercolor paper and white gouache at an art store. 

The Hotdog stand we were going to get food at closed.  So instead we went to the French Bread Co-Op acrossed the street from the Orange Peel. The store was, I don't know, pretentious.  They sold only organic products.  I really don't know how one would afford shopping there on a regular basis.  We bought wheat bread rolls, sharp cheddar and gouda cheese and juice spritzers (aka. Soda pop)  We ate this food while in line waiting to claim our tickets.  

SOLD OUT. 

Paul's brother brian didn't get to go and that was saddening. 

But we had bought tickets about a week ago and so we got in... 

We claimed some good spots before the show.  We were surrounded by obvious devoted Decemberist fans who couldn't shutup about the songs they wanted to hear.  "Sons and Daughters" had been touring with Decemberists and they opened last night.  It was a pretty powerful performance.  They have a lot of energy.  They're a Scottish band who has folk-rockish sounds.  The women wore red dresses and black boots.  The two male members looked liked soften greasers. 

Paul instigated the popping of a green balloon that was being bounced around the crowd.

So yeah the Decemberists! They came on stage, Colin was wearing a white striped suit with a blue tie and jeans. Paul will supply the setlist online at some point I'm sure.  All sorts of strange things happened during their performance.  There was a Grasshopper flying around the front of the stage.  Colin announces that we all should buy the new Myla Goldberg Book. (which means he's going to play his song about myla goldberg next)
During a pause Paul yells out to colin what he thinks about the movie. (there's some movie about myla goldberg coming out)
Colin replies
"What? But it isn't out yet is it?" 
"No but, I mean .. do you think it will be good"
Then Colin gets distracted by the said grasshopper and asks the audience if its a bat.  
There's an intermission and the lights go on so that they can save the grasshopper.  The bassist finds a clear cup and releases the creature out the side door. Then the show starts back up again. 
Colin announces he's going to be playing songs about prostitutes and other characters and Paul yells out "and Chimbley Sweeps!!"
Colin looks back over to Paul and says "... no.. Ryan is not here this time around so we can't play that one unfortunately... " and then the entire audience goes "aww...."

Okay so they played a certain song and the Drummer and Chris Funk wandered through the crowd banging the drum and cymbals,  They cut a path right next to Paul and myself.  So that was pretty damn cool. 

Let me say that there was about 10x more energy this show than the last time they played in Asheville.  They came out for an encore to play their final song: The Mariner's Revenge Song. Hell yes.  It took them a while. but they came back out.  The audience was going wild.  Chris Funk had made this stage prop that was fashioned to look like giant whales teeth.  It was awesome.  Colin had us do the whalish groaning during that part of the song. That song is so awesome.  I'd like to see more material like that from them. 

During the song the whole floor was bouncing.  Everyone was jumping up and down. It was probably the wildest show I've been to. 

I'll end on that note. Man. That was great.

Lately these weeks have been shedding themselves like dead skin.  There have been parties just about every day.   I never used to go to parties that often, I guess stuff changes.  It's not exactly my last year at college.

So Thomas and Vinny held a private show: The Terrific Whistlers, Fire Island, AK, Thom Blood, and Thanksgiving.  
It was a pretty impressive set. Very intimate, as it was held in their 3 room flat with a small european bathroom.  It felt like bread and other foods should have been baking in the oven. Adrian's a nice guy.  His toes are longer than my fingers. Weird. 

If I have anything to drink I get extremely neurotic and talkative and sometimes very very affectionate. It's probably a good thing that I don't buy alcohol really all that often.  Though, apparently its somewhat entertaining.  I was thinking more along the lines of annoying. 

Anyhow, Decemberists today. I probably won't feel the actual excitement of it until after the whole show... That's how it is.

I think I have a bizarre tendency to treat certain women, generally the more interesting or attractive ones, with an insulting or judgemental tone.  It is a tone I do not take with guys.  I cannot really explain it completely.  I know that it is related to my flirtatious nature which has been called "playground-like" or "mean." I know that it also has something to do with my need to be around strong women. Women who can throw back the same types of jabs and  put me in my place. A place which should be somewhere leveled with them. I like that.  A sick and twisted part of myself likes to see women, and all people, snap and turn to the point of anger. Because anger is anything but dull. 

Of course. It could just be pent up sexual frustration and my id's general hatred of myself for having so much criteria to follow through with the release of that sexuality. 

None of it really matters. I'll try to catch my tongue when I'm being an exceptional jerk.  but only an exceptional one.
photos of it later.

hello world.



MY BRAIN IS TO X-PLODE!!!!

Prof. David Brown was late for class this morning by about five minutes.  He had just returned from the airport after saying bye to his college graduate daughter.  She parted for London.  Fucking LONDON. Its not a career related move, rather, it is experience related.  She wanted to just experience London.  How fucking cool is that?  I think I need to do something similiar after I graduate.  Get a normal job in London and work for my rent. Just to soak up a european world would be well worth it.  Who's with me?

The nineiron website is nearing completion.  For those of you who don't know what I'm talking about, nineiron is a group of underground comics by Paul, Jon, and myself.  We each have our own stories and they all rock very hard.  Originally we were going to do self-published zines with our comics every month but after making the teaser issue we soon realized it was a bit too much work for what it was worth. And so instead of abandoning the project we chose to turn them into online webcomics which should have a page a week for each comic.  We'll still advertise the the site with flyers, and even put together another teaser issue this year pretty soon just for kicks.  We'll have a domain for it as well. Jon's saying he'll host it for the time being.  

I just hope we can get the site done this weekend.  It's a lot of tedious work, especially when you got graded projects and shortstories to be concerned with.
Ah yes. This is my season folks.

Sometimes, when I'm walking home and I am listening to godspeed I pretend that there are people following me or chasing me in cars or on bicycles. 
I hide in the shadows; like batman. 

seriously this happens on a regular basis.

but only if I'm listening to godspeed. Dun-dun-Dun!

But its because I care about the well-being of those who are important me.
